column4: Why might a command I place in a startup script not run on startup, but it does when i run it from a terminal?
what does the command do?  or better, what is the command?
it is the deluged daemon. I run it after I run "deluge --ui web -l /var/www/deluge.log"
so what was the exact command you placed in the startup file? i'm assuming this is the gnome startup file? i wonder why you aren't using the session properties dialog to place this command in?

the exact line is "deluged", deluged is just the daemon for the deluge bittorrent client. It is placed in a file called /etc/init.d/startup that also contains some other commands that fix my wireless card, etc. on startup. After startup, ps aux | grep deluge does not show that the daemon is running. If I run sudo /etc/init.d/startup from a terminal and then list services, it shows that deluged is running fine and e

making a startup script and placing it in /etc/init.d does not automatically make it run when you enter a runlevel .. you need to enable that script for the runlevel you usually work in (by default is it 2) .. have you enabled the script in runlevel 2?
yep, ive done that. it runs on startup, every other line executes, jsut not this one
can i have a look at that script on a pastebin?
http://pastebin.com/m24eaa96e
I will admit it's kind of rigged up, but the networking stuff works :-D
i don't use deluge - but do you know if it is safe to run deluge as root like you are trying to do?  some apps will simply not run as root?
also, there might be a switch to deluge to have it run in the background.  deluge -d perhaps?
I have started it with sudo at it will run.
deluge doesnt list such an option
what you could do is log commands - like this. http://pastebin.com/d288b8e86
alright, i'll test it out
The log only contains what was echoed out by the startup script, no errors.
hmm, maybe have a look through /var/log/{messages,dmesg}  to see if deluge exited abnormally.
nothing there abnormal
Some of the documentation recommends starting the daemon with inittab: http://forum.deluge-torrent.org/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=3185
heh.  /usr/bin/deluged -d -p 58846 &> /var/log/deluged.log # sounds to me like this starts the daemon
that was from the same page you are looking at there
